unnormalised: The monsoon had just started its gentle caress of Kerala, turning the world outside a vibrant, saturated green. I remember Amma switching on the news; the anchor, a sharp-dressed woman, was talking about a new government scheme, “PM SHRI Yojana.” I was probably 10 or 11, more interested in my comics, but the name stuck. Amma, a primary school teacher in our small village, was always keen on any news related to education. She believed education was the only way for children like me, from a modest background, to climb the ladder of opportunity.
normalised: The monsoon had just started its gentle caress of Kerala, turning the world outside a vibrant, saturated green. I remember Amma switching on the news; the anchor, a sharp-dressed woman, was talking about a new government scheme, “P-M S-H-R-I Yojana.” I was probably ten or eleven, more interested in my comics, but the name stuck. Amma, a primary school teacher in our small village, was always keen on any news related to education. She believed education was the only way for children like me, from a modest background, to climb the ladder of opportunity.

unnormalised: I didn’t pay much attention back then. My focus was on acing my maths exam – Mr. Nair, our teacher, was notoriously strict. But over the years, I heard Amma mention the scheme multiple times, often during her conversations with other teachers in the staff room, snippets of which I overheard while waiting for her after school. They would discuss the finer points, how schools could apply, the potential benefits for the students. I vaguely understood it was aimed at upgrading existing schools, turning them into model schools showcasing the best of the National Education Policy (NEP) 2020.

unnormalised: Fast forward a few years. I was in 12th standard, preparing for my NEET exams, burning the midnight oil. My younger sister, Lakshmi, was now in the same primary school where Amma taught. One day, Amma came home beaming. Their school, the Government Upper Primary School, Kallara, had been selected under the PM SHRI Yojana! The excitement in our house was palpable. This meant better infrastructure, improved teaching methods, and a more conducive learning environment for Lakshmi and all the other children.
normalised: Fast forward a few years. I was in twelfth standard, preparing for my N-E-E-T exams, burning the midnight oil. My younger sister, Lakshmi, was now in the same primary school where Amma taught. One day, Amma came home beaming. Their school, the Government Upper Primary School, Kallara, had been selected under the P-M S-H-R-I Yojana! The excitement in our house was palpable. This meant better infrastructure, improved teaching methods, and a more conducive learning environment for Lakshmi and all the other children.

unnormalised: The transformation was gradual but significant. Initially, the school received a grant of ₹50 lakhs for infrastructure development. They started by renovating the classrooms, painting them in bright, cheerful colors. New furniture arrived, replacing the old, rickety benches. A small computer lab was set up with 10 computers, a boon for students who had never even touched a mouse before. The school library, previously a dusty room with a handful of books, was revamped with new titles catering to all age groups. It even got air-conditioning! Amma always tells us the library renovation costed about Rs. 2.5 lakh.

They started by renovating the classrooms, painting them in bright, cheerful colors. New furniture arrived, replacing the old, rickety benches. The school library, previously a dusty room with a handful of books, was revamped with new titles catering to all age groups. It even got air-conditioning! Amma always tells us the library renovation costed about rupees two point five lakh.

unnormalised: The teachers, too, underwent extensive training programs. Amma attended a 5-day workshop in Thiruvananthapuram focusing on incorporating experiential learning and innovative teaching methods. She came back energized, full of new ideas. The results were evident. Lakshmi, usually a reluctant student, started enjoying school. Her grades improved, and she developed a genuine interest in learning. The PM SHRI Yojana wasn't just about buildings and equipment; it was about empowering teachers and creating a more engaging learning experience.

unnormalised: Now, years later, I am pursuing my MBBS at AIIMS Delhi. Lakshmi is preparing for her own NEET exams. When I visit home, I make it a point to visit her school. It’s a completely different place from what it was when I was a child. The school has smart boards in every classroom, a well-equipped science lab, and even a small playground with modern equipment. The PM SHRI Yojana has not only transformed the physical infrastructure but has also instilled a sense of pride and ownership among the students, teachers, and the community. Amma says, "The scheme has given a new lease of life to government schools like ours, bridging the gap with private institutions and providing quality education to children from all backgrounds, especially in rural areas like Kallara - postcode 695609." It's a testament to the power of well-planned government initiatives and the unwavering dedication of teachers like my Amma. The positive impact is immeasurable, shaping the future of countless children, one school at a time.
